questions.text: What is the doubling time of Mycobacterium leprae?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • Doubling Time: It is the interval needed for a bacterial population to double in size Mycobacterium leprae has an exceptionally slow doubling time of about 12 to 14 days.
  • This slow replication rate contributes to the chronic nature of leprosy and the difficulty in culturing the bacteria in vitro.
  • The prolonged doubling time leads to a delay in diagnosis, slow progression or chronicity of the disease, difficulty to culture in vitro and slow response to treatment.

Leprosy spreads via aerosol and the portal of entry is the respiratory tract. The latent period of leprosy, is variable and is unusually long. It can last from a few weeks to up to 20 years. However, the average incubation period of the disease is 2-7 years.

questions.text: All except are part of Ridely-Jopling classification except :
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Pure Neuritic leprosy is not part of the Ridley-Jopling classification.

The Ridley-Jopling classification of leprosy is based on clinical, histopathological, bacteriological, and immunological criteria and includes the following spectrum:

  1. TT – Tuberculoid
  2. BT – Borderline tuberculoid
  3. BB – Borderline borderline
  4. BL – Borderline lepromatous
  5. LL – Lepromatous

This classification reflects the immunological status of the patient, ranging from strong cell-mediated immunity (TT) to poor immunity (LL).

The New Indian Classification (1981) is different and it includes: Indeterminate (I), Tuberculoid (T), Borderline (B), Lepromatous (L) and Polyneuritic (P)

questions.text: Which is the least commonly encountered form of leprosy
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

  • BB leprosy is the immunologic midpoint in the clinical spectrum of the leprosy.
  • It is the most unstable and uncommon form. These patients upgrade or downgrade to a more stable clinical form at the earliest.
  • Cutaneous lesions are characteristically annular plaques with sharp interior and exterior border - inverted cup saucer appearance.

Explanation of other options:

Borderline Tuberculoid (Option A):

This form lies near the tuberculoid end of the spectrum. It is relatively common because many patients present with partial cell-mediated immunity. It manifests with a limited number of skin lesions and asymmetric nerve involvement.
Incorrect because it is more frequently encountered than Borderline Borderline.

Borderline Lepromatous (Option C): This form is closer to the lepromatous pole. It is more common than Borderline Borderline and presents with multiple, less defined lesions and more symmetrical nerve involvement.Incorrect because it is seen more frequently than Borderline Borderline.

Lepromatous (Option D): This is a very common form of leprosy, especially in patients with poor cell-mediated immunity. It presents with widespread skin lesions, symmetrical nerve involvement, and a high bacillary load.Incorrect because it is among the most frequently encountered forms of leprosy, particularly in endemic regions.

questions.text: The most common type of Leprosy in India is
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Borderline Tuberculoid s is the most frequently seen form of leprosy in India. It lies on the tuberculoid side of the Ridley-Jopling spectrum and is characterized by:

  • Few to several well-demarcated hypopigmented skin lesions
  • Asymmetric peripheral nerve involvement
  • Partial cell-mediated immunity - enough to limit bacterial proliferation, but not enough for complete clearance
  • Negative or weakly positive slit-skin smears
  • Pseudopodia like extensions

It is common in India due to the overall moderate immune response found in most individuals exposed to Mycobacterium leprae in endemic settings.

The upper arm of an Indian man showing a typical dry, hairless, hypopigmented plaque with a scaly, red edge. Such Lesions are usually anaesthetic.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Tuberculoid Leprosy (Option A):

This form shows very strong cell-mediated immunity with typically one or two lesions and often a positive lepromin test.

Incorrect because it is less common than borderline tuberculoid in the population, though it may be seen in individuals with very robust immune responses.

Borderline Lepromatous (Option C):

This form is closer to the lepromatous pole and presents with more numerous and less defined lesions. It reflects a lower cell-mediated immunity.

Incorrect because it is less prevalent in India compared to borderline tuberculoid.

Lepromatous Leprosy (Option D):

This form occurs in patients with poor cell-mediated immunity. It shows widespread, symmetric lesions and a high bacillary load.

Incorrect because although common, it is not as frequent as borderline tuberculoid in India.

questions.text: Which of the following are cardinal features of leprosy?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

The 3 cardinal features of leprosy include :

  • A definite loss of sensation in a hypopigmented or erythematous skin lesion.
  • A thickened or enlarged peripheral nerve with a loss of sensation and/or weakness in the muscles supplied by the nerve
  • The presence of acid-fast bacilli in an SSS.

Either one is enough to make a diagnosis of leprosy

Thickened anterior and posterior tibial nerves

Single and clusters of acid-fast bacilli seen

questions.text: Which of the following lesions are not seen in leprosy:
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Leprosy skin lesions can be single or multiple, usually hypopigmented/reddish.
  • A variety of skin lesions may be seen but macules (flat), papules (raised), or nodules are common but never present with vesicles.
  • Sensory loss is a typical feature of leprosy, the initial sensation to go is thermal.
  • Thickened nerves, mainly peripheral nerve trunks constitute another feature of leprosy, accompanied by other signs as a result of damage to the nerve.
  • These may be loss of sensation in the skin and weakness of muscles supplied by the affected nerve.
  • Positive Slit Skin Smear examination: Modified Ziehl Nielson staining : Rod-shaped, red-stained leprosy bacilli, which are diagnostic of the disease.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Macule (Option A): Macules are flat, hypopigmented or erythematous skin lesions. These are often the earliest presentation in tuberculoid and borderline forms of leprosy.
  • Papule (Option B): Papules are raised solid lesions, and they can be seen in various stages of leprosy, especially in borderline and lepromatous types.
    Incorrect because papules are a recognized cutaneous lesion in leprosy.
  • Nodule (Option D): Nodules are firm, raised lesions, typically found in lepromatous leprosy due to the massive infiltration of bacilli-laden macrophages.
    Incorrect because nodules are classic in advanced or multibacillary leprosy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male had multiple hypoanesthetic mildly erythematous large plaques on trunk and extremities. His ulnar and lateral popliteal nerves on both sides were enlarged. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis is borderline lepromatous leprosy because of the symmetrical and bilateral nerve enlargement, a key feature of the lepromatous end of the leprosy spectrum. In contrast, the tuberculoid end typically presents with asymmetrical nerve involvement. The presence of multiple, large plaques further confirms a borderline condition

questions.text: Satellite lesion is seen in which type of leprosy ?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Borderline tuberculoid leprosy (BT) presents with single or a few lesions only, but margin of the lesion is not so sharply demarcated from the surrounding normal skin, and there may be a few satellite lesions around the main lesions.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tuberculoid Leprosy (Option A):
This form usually presents with a single or few well-demarcated hypopigmented macules or plaques. The lesions are dry, anesthetic, and sharply marginated. Satellite lesions are not a feature of this type.

Lepromatous Leprosy (Option B):
Lepromatous leprosy is characterized by multiple symmetric skin lesions, including nodules, plaques, and diffuse infiltration. The lesions are widespread but not arranged in a satellite pattern.

Histoid Leprosy (Option D):
Histoid leprosy is a variant of lepromatous leprosy, presenting with well-defined, shiny, firm nodules often over apparently normal skin. The lesion distribution is random and does not form satellite arrangements.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple hypo-aesthetic patches on limb and trunk with bilateral symmetrical nerve thickening. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Multiple lesions on limb and trunk with bilateral symmetric nerve thickening are pointing towards the lepromatous end of the spectrum, which could be BL or LL.
  • BL - hypoesthetic lesions
  • LL - normoesthetic lesions and glove and stocking type anesthesia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Borderline Borderline (Option A):
BB is immunologically unstable and relatively rare. Lesions may vary in shape and size, and nerve involvement is present but not typically symmetrical. It does not usually show extensive or symmetrical nerve thickening.

Lepromatous Leprosy (Option C):
LL shows diffuse skin involvement, often without clear-cut patches. Nerve involvement is symmetrical and severe, but anesthesia is late to develop. The presence of discrete hypo-aesthetic patches points more toward BL than LL.

Borderline Tuberculoid (Option D):
BT typically presents with few, asymmetrically distributed hypo-pigmented patches and asymmetrical nerve thickening. The number of lesions and extent of nerve involvement in this case is too extensive for BT.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male from a leprosy-endemic region presents with a progressive thickening of the facial skin, leading to a lion-like appearance. He also reports loss of eyebrows and eyelashes, along with numbness over his hands and feet. On examination, there is bilateral ulnar nerve enlargement. A skin smear stained with Ziehl-Neelsen reveals numerous acid-fast bacilli. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lepromatous leprosy is characterized by a poor cellular immune response, leading to extensive skin involvement and peripheral nerve damage.
  • Leonine's lion-like appearance is a classic feature of this form of leprosy, resulting from thickened, infiltrated skin and loss of facial features.

Leonine facies are seen in

  1. LL- Leprosy
  2. Paget's disease of bone
  3. Fibrous dysplasia
  4. Hyperphosphatemia

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculoid leprosy(Option A):It is Characterized by Few hypopigmented anesthetic patches,Asymmetrical nerve involvement.Does not present with leonine facies or diffuse infiltration.

Scleroderma(Option C):May present with skin thickening, but usually begins in hands and face, associated with Raynaud’s phenomenon, tightening rather than nodular thickening.No nerve involvement or AFB positivity.No leonine facies or madarosis.

Lucio leprosy (Lucio phenomenon)(Option D):A rare variant of diffuse lepromatous leprosy. It is Characterized by Diffuse skin infiltration without nodules,Extensive necrotic ulcerations due to vascular involvement.

questions.text: A 24 year old male patient presents with a single hypopigmented anesthetic patch on the arm. The clinician suspects early leprosy. During sensory testing, which modality should be examined first, as it is typically the earliest to be lost?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The earliest sensation to be lost in leprosy is temperature discrimination. Mycobacterium leprae affects small, unmyelinated or thinly myelinated sensory fibers early.These fibers transmit Temperature,
  • It begins with inability to differentiate between hot and cold.Next is pain, followed by fine touch and deep touch.

questions.text: Which is the most common nerve involved in leprosy?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Leprosy preferentially involves superficially located nerves like the median nerve at the wrist, the ulnar nerve at the elbow, and the common peroneal nerve at the fibular head (due to relatively cooler tissue temperatures). Ulnar nerve is the most common nerve involved in leprosy. Once affected it causes claw hand deformity( Ulnar claw).

Blue, beaded bacilli suggestive of non-tuberculous mycobacteria

questions.text: A 40-year-old male from a leprosy-endemic area presents with multiple skin lesions and sensory loss. A slit-skin smear is taken and stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen technique. Under oil immersion, several clumps of organisms are seen. Which of the following best describes this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • "Globi" or globus formation refers to clumps of Mycobacterium leprae seen in multibacillary leprosy inside macrophage cells.
  • They appear as acid-fast (red) bacilli in macrophages under Ziehl–Neelsen stain.This pattern is characteristic of lepromatous or multibacillary disease.

'Globi'

Explanation of other options:

Blue, beaded bacilli suggestive of non-tuberculous mycobacteria(Option B): Non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM) can show beaded acid-fast rods, but they do not form globi, and typically occur in environmental infections, not in classic leprosy lesions.

Chains of cocci consistent with staphylococcal colonization(option C):Cocci in chains are characteristic of Streptococcus species, not seen with Ziehl–Neelsen stain, which targets acid-fast bacteria.

Negatively stained spiral organisms suggesting syphilis(Option D):Spiral organisms (spirochetes) are visualized using dark-field microscopy or immunofluorescence, not by Ziehl–Neelsen stain.

questions.text: In which type of leprosy is cell-mediated immunity maximally suppressed?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Lepromatous leprosy lies at the anergic pole of the Ridley-Jopling spectrum. It is marked by:

  • Complete absence of cell-mediated immunity (CMI) to Mycobacterium leprae
  • Widespread skin lesions and symmetric nerve involvement
  • High bacillary load due to the immune system's failure to control the infection
  • Negative lepromin test

The severe suppression of CMI in LL leads to the uncontrolled proliferation of bacilli and dissemination of the disease.

Explanation of Other Options:

Indeterminate Leprosy (Option A):
This is an early, non-specific form of leprosy seen in initial stages. CMI is not completely suppressed and may evolve toward either tuberculoid or lepromatous depending on host immunity.

Tuberculoid Leprosy (Option B):
In this form, CMI is strong and effective, leading to limited skin lesions, granuloma formation, and very low or absent bacillary load. The Lepromin test is strongly positive.

Borderline Leprosy (Option D):
Borderline types (BT, BB, BL) show variable and unstable CMI. Immunity is partially suppressed, depending on the position within the borderline spectrum, but not completely lost as in lepromatous leprosy.

questions.text: Negative Slit skin smear staining is seen in which of the following leprosy:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

In pure neuritic type there is nerve involvement but no skin lesion. These cases are bacteriologically always negative.

Slit Skin Smear Staining in Leprosy:

Purpose: To detect the presence of Mycobacterium leprae (the bacteria that causes leprosy) in the skin.

Procedure:

  1. A small cut (slit) is made in the skin, usually from active lesion sites or cooler areas like earlobes.
  2. Material is scraped from the slit to collect cells and bacteria.
  3. The sample is spread on a glass slide and stained using special stains (most commonly Ziehl-Neelsen stain) that highlight acid-fast bacilli (AFB).

Result:

  • If bacteria are seen (red rods under microscope), it confirms the diagnosis of leprosy.
  • The number of bacilli can be counted and expressed as the Bacterial Index (BI), indicating bacterial load.
  • Helps classify the disease type and monitor treatment response.

Explanation of Other Options:

Borderline (Option A):
Borderline leprosy includes BT, BB, and BL forms, which often have visible skin lesions and a variable bacillary load. Depending on the subtype, the slit skin smear may be positive, especially in BB and BL types.

Lepromatous (Option B):
Lepromatous leprosy has a very high bacterial index, with numerous bacilli present in skin and other tissues. Slit skin smear is strongly positive in this form.

Indeterminate (Option D):
In indeterminate leprosy, the bacterial load is usually very low, but not always absent. SSS may be negative or sometimes weakly positive, but this form still includes visible skin lesions, unlike neuritic leprosy.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy from Nepal presents with a 6 months history of an non-itchy,ill-defined hypopigmented macule on the face. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The lesions of indeterminate leprosy are very subtle. Common in children living in endemic areas. Solitary, ill defined macule with slight atrophy, normal sensation.

Intermediate leprosy.The face of a Nepali child showing vague hypopigmented patches with some central healing.

Histopathology Examination: Perineural and periappendageal lymphocytic infiltrate

(a) Intermediate leprosy,low power view( H&E) showing minimal perineurovasculqr inflammation in the mid-dermis.

(b)High-power view(Wade-Fite stain) showing one acid-fast bacillus in a Schwann cell

Explanation of other options:

  • Pityriasis alba( Option A): A common benign skin condition in children, presenting as ill-defined, hypopigmented, scaly patches, typically on the face, often linked to mild eczema or dry skin.
  • Morphoea( Option C): Also called localized scleroderma, it presents as localized, hardened, shiny, and depigmented or hyperpigmented skin patches due to excess collagen deposition.
  • Calcium deficiency(Option D): May cause dry, scaly skin, muscle cramps, and brittle nails, but does not typically present as well-defined hypopigmented skin lesions.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Lucio phenomenon is a severe necrotizing skin reaction seen in Lucio leprosy.
Reason (R): Lucio leprosy is associated with Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes infarction due to obstructive vasculopathy.
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Lucio phenomenon is a distinct necrotizing skin reaction that happens only in Lucio leprosy, not in other forms of leprosy.
  • The underlying cause is infarction of the skin due to obstructive vasculopathy—this leads to bullae, necrosis, and deep ulcers.

Lucio leprosy has been linked to Mycobacterium lepromatosis, a species closely related to M. leprae.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Type 1 Lepra reaction?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Systemic symptoms are mild in type 1 lepra reaction and are more prominent in lepra-2 reactions.
  • Type 1 lepra reaction is a sudden change in the cell-mediated immune response to Mycobacterium leprae antigens, seen mainly in the borderline spectrum of leprosy (BT, BB, BL). It manifests as an acute inflammatory episode, often triggered by initiation of treatment, stress, or infections.

Explanation of Other Options:

Seen in borderline cases (Option A):
Type 1 reaction is typically seen in patients with borderline forms of leprosy (BT, BB, BL) as their immune response shifts. It is not seen in purely tuberculoid or lepromatous poles.

Existing lesions of leprosy get inflamed (Option C):
This is a classic feature of Type 1 reaction. The pre-existing lesions become erythematous, edematous, and painful, often accompanied by nerve involvement.

Occurs within the first year of starting the treatment (Option D):
Type 1 reactions frequently occur soon after starting multidrug therapy (MDT), often within the first 6 to 12 months, as the immune system begins to respond to dying bacilli.

questions.text: What is the Treatment of choice for a patient with leprosy presenting with severe neuritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • For any complication of leprosy antileprotic drugs shouldn't be stopped
  • Neuritis, such as nerve tenderness, newly developed sensory loss, and/or motor weakness.
  • Neuritis in leprosy is a type of immunological reaction which needs corticosteroids to suppress the nerve inflammation hence the best answer is Multi Drug Therapy with corticosteroids.

Explanation of other options:

MDT only(Option B):MDT treats the infection but does not address inflammation or nerve damage.Using MDT alone may lead to permanent nerve function loss due to ongoing neuritis.

Corticosteroids only(Option C):It helps with inflammation and nerve function preservation, but does not eliminate the infection.

Clofazimine(Option D): It is part of MDT (especially for MB leprosy) and has some anti-inflammatory effect, but it is not sufficient for treating severe neuritis.Cannot replace corticosteroids in acute neuritis.

questions.text: The Daily dose of thalidomide for controlling ENL is:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Erythema nodosum leprosum(ENL) or Type 2 lepra reactions occur in patients with multibacillary disease (LL and BL). The most effective drug for ENL is thalidomide. For patients with chronic ENL the usual initial dosage of 200 mg twice a day. Thalidomide (400 mg daily) is superior to steroids in controlling ENL and is the drug of choice in severe Thalidomide is highly teratogenic and can cause birth defects (eg. Phocomelia) when taken during pregnancy.
  • ENL presents as painful red nodules on the face and extensor limbs, which may be superficial or deep, and can show suppuration, ulceration, or induration in chronic cases. Lesions appear in crops, desquamate, and fade over days. It is a systemic disorder with fever, malaise, and may involve uveitis, dactylitis, arthritis, neuritis, lymphadenitis, myositis, and orchitis.

Type 2 reaction in Lepromatous leprosy in a Nigerian man: Erythema nodosum leprosum. Several of the reaction nodules have broken down, releasing pus.
